Therefore, the dominant time scales found using MF-TW-DFA also capture the corresponding temporal dynamics, such as white noise, red noise and correlation structure, which allows us to construct stochastic models for the observed processes, such as the statistical structure and dynamics of sea-ice velocity fields [ 24]. The ‘crossover’ or ‘dominant’ time scale is defined as that at which the fluctuation function log 10 F 2( s) changes slope with respect to log 10 s.
